body_html:
That's kind of odd, since I got it to work in Python 2.7.3. (And it fixed my version of the bug )

Was virtualenv still activated in your shell session? To be clear, the full command sequence would be:

# assuming we want to be working within ~/tensorflow
virtualenv --system-site-packages ~/tensorflow
cd ~/tensorflow
source bin/activate
# we are now "inside the virtual environment", and ./bin is at the beginning of $PATH
pip --version    # Here I had version 1.1
pip install --upgrade pip
pip --version    # ...and now it says 7.1.2
# In the following use "/cpu/" or "/gpu" as desired
pip install --upgrade https://storage.googleapis.com/tensorflow/linux/cpu/tensorflow-0.5.0-cp27-none-linux_x86_64.whl
# (we would continue with tensorflow setup/testing here)
# when done, we could exit the shell completely, or just leave virtualenv with this command:
deactivate
# Now the prompt and $PATH are back to normal

body:
That's kind of odd, since I got it to work in Python 2.7.3. (And it fixed [my version of the bug](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/46) )

Was virtualenv still activated in your shell session? To be clear, the full command sequence would be:

```
# assuming we want to be working within ~/tensorflow
virtualenv --system-site-packages ~/tensorflow
cd ~/tensorflow
source bin/activate
# we are now "inside the virtual environment", and ./bin is at the beginning of $PATH
pip --version    # Here I had version 1.1
pip install --upgrade pip
pip --version    # ...and now it says 7.1.2
# In the following use "/cpu/" or "/gpu" as desired
pip install --upgrade https://storage.googleapis.com/tensorflow/linux/cpu/tensorflow-0.5.0-cp27-none-linux_x86_64.whl
# (we would continue with tensorflow setup/testing here)
# when done, we could exit the shell completely, or just leave virtualenv with this command:
deactivate
# Now the prompt and $PATH are back to normal
```
